bibl.title: Chin Hing v. United States of America. Deposition
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US District Court Western Division of Washington, Seattle

div1.p: In the United States District Court, for the Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the matter of Chin Hing
#2857 Deposition of Louis F. Post, upon the annexed interrogatoriesand cross interrogatories, at Washington D.C.

Be it remembered that at an examination of witneses under the Commission of this Honorable Court, begun on the 11th day of November, pursuant to a subpoena issued by the Clerk of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, personally appeared before me, Thomas G. Lewis, Commissioner, the within named Louis F. Post, who being produced as a witness of lawful age for and on behalf of the Petitioner, Ching Hing, and being first duly sworn and cautioned to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth, touching the matter at issue in the above-entitled cause, did depose and say as follows:
(1) I am the Assistant Secretary of Labor. I am qualified on the 9th of June, 1913.

(2) That question relates to the internal administration of the Departmentand I regard it as calling for an answer that might be prejudicial to the public interest. For this reason I decline to answer until instructed otherwise by the Secretary of Labor
(3) Solicitorof the Department of Justice for the Department of Labor.
(4) Same response as to Question 2
(5) Same answer as to Questions 2 and 4.
(6) I am acquainted with a decision by Judge Dooling of the Federal Court at San Franscisco which is the decision to which I suppose reference is made by the question.
(7)Same response as to Question 2.
(8)Same response as to Question 2.
(9) In so far as that applies to immigration cases the response is the same as the response to Question 2. Speaking generally, I am Acting Secretary in the absence of the Secretary.
(10)Same response as to Question 2.
(11)Same response as to Question 2.
(12)Same response as to Question 2.
Answers of Mr. Post to Cross Interrogatories

(1) That question relates to the internal administration of the Department and I regard it as calling for an answer that might be prejudicial to the public interest. For this reason I decline to answer until instructed otherwise by the Secretary of Labor.
(2) Same response as to Cross Interrogatory 1.
(3) Same response as to Cross Interrogatory 1.
(4) Same response as to Cross Interrogatory 1.
(5) Same response as to Cross Interrogatory 1.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 11th day of November, 1914. Louis F. Post
Thomas G Lewis Notary Public and Commissioner

p.add: Adjourned to Monday, November 16, 1914, at three o'clock PM Thomas G Lewis Commissioner

div1.p: Monday, November 16, 1914: Adjourned to Monday, November 23rd, 1914, at 3 pm, pending determination of a certifiateto the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia which set up the fact that the witness Post had refused to answer interrogatories and cross interrogatories. Thomas G Lewis Commissioner
Monday, November 23, 1914: Adjourned to Friday, Nov. 27 at 3:30 p.m. pending determination of the Court upon Certificate, Rule and Return. Thomas G Lewis Commissioner.
Friday, November 27, 1914: Adjourned to Friday, December 4, 1914, at 3:30pm Thomas G Lewis Comissioner.

Personally appeared before me, Thomas G. Lewis, Notary Public and Commissioner, pursuant to notice, Corry M. Stadden, who being produced as witness to lawful age for and on behalfof the Petitioner, Ching Hing, and being first duly sworn according to law, upon Interrogatories and Cross Interrogatories, did depose and say as follows:
(1) Corry M. Stadden, attorney at law.
(2) Yes.
(3) I did.

(4) Louis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of Labor was present and on duty in the Department of Labor on September 24th, 25th, and 26th, 1914. I am not certain whether Secretary Wilson was on duty on those dates or not, as I was more particular in satisfying myself that Assistant Secretary Post was on duty, particularly on September 26th.
(5) I was notified on September 26th that Mr. J. B. Sensmore, as "Acting Secretary" of Labor had affirmed the decision to deport Ching Hing. The record will show.
(6) Assistant Secretary Post was on duty September 26. I visited his office to satisfy myself that he was there on that date.
(7) Judge M. T. Dooling, in the U.S. District Court, sitting at San Franciso, In re Quan Wy Chung, No. 15687, has so held.

(8) Quoting from a certified copy of the opinion In re Quan Wy Chung, Judge Dooling said in part as follows: "Whoever, therefore, challenges his right to act must assume the burden of proving clearly, that his action was not had in the 'Absence of the Secretary and Assistant Secretary'. But however inconvenient it may be, if the Secretary and Assistant are not absent, and particularly if both are present, his performance of the duties of the Secretary is unauthorized, either by the Statute, or the order of the President. In the case at barit is practically conceded, and conclusively established, that the appeal was not determined by the Acting Secretary in the absence of the Secretary and
Assistant Secretary, but that, on the contrary both were present, and performing the duties of their office at the time the appeal was determined. The appellant were by law to have their appeal heard and determined by him except as above stated, and the determination of their appeal by another not authorized, is neither a fair hearing, nor due process of law".
this opinion was filed by Judge Dooling with the Clerk of his Court, October 23rd, 1914, as appears on the certified copy.
Answersof Mr. Stadden to Cross Interrogatories:
(1) I was not.But I satisfied myself that Assistant Secretary Post was not considering the Ching Hing appeal, though on duty in the Department.

(2) By seeing the word "approved" or "affirmed" and the initials of Mr. Densmore, "J.B.D." on the memorandum prepared in the Bureau of Immigration which recommended exclusion. I also knew personally that Mr. Densmore was assuming to act upon this case as "Acting Secretary" regardless of the fact that Assistant Secretary Post was on duty at that time.
Corry M. Stadden
Subscribed and sworn to before me, Thomas G Lewis Notary Public, D.C. and Commissioner.
Adjourned until further notice pending the order of the Court (Mr. Justice Gould) upon the Rule to Show Cause, issued against the witness, Louis F. Post, herein. Thomas G Lewis Commissioner.

June 10th, 1915: Further proceedings under this Commission hereby suspended upon advice of Corry M. Stadden, cousel for Ching Hing that he is informedthat the Petition of Habeas Corpus herein has been dismissed. The Order of Mr. Justice Gould, of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia, commanding the witness Louis F. Post to appear and answer question, was signed this day and a true copy is appended hereto. Thomas G Lewis Commissioner.
